citation.article-title: The sporogenous sulfate reducing bacterium Desulfotomaculum guttoideum sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Desulfotomaculum guttoideum sp. nov.
Desulfotomaculum guttoideum (gut.to.l'de.um. Latin fem. noun. gutta crop; Latin suffix, -ide like; guttoideum droplike)
Spor-forming, rod-shaped bacteria, 1.0 by 2.3 μm ocuurring singly and in pairs.
Spores are round and terminal; cells enlarge during sporulation and acquire a tear-drop form.
Peritrichous flagella.
Gram-negative.
Obligate anaerobe.
Sulfate, sulfite, and thiosulfate are used as electron acceptors and reduced to hydrogen sulfide; elemental sulfur is not reduced.
Pyruvate can be used as the carbon source and in the absence of reducible sulfur compounds as the energy substrate.
On media with lactate or MPB, it grows only in the presence of reducible sulfur compounds.
It does not grow on media with formate, acetate, malate, alanine, ethanol, methanol, and cellulose.
It does not grow under autotrophic conditions on a medium with hydrogen and carbonates.
Optimum temperature for growth is 31-32°C.
Optimal pH is 7.4.
It does not require NaCl.
Desulfoviridin is not present in cells.
Cytochrome c is the predominant cytochrome.
Hydrogenase is localized in the cell periplasm.
The nucleotide composition of the DNA: 51.6 ± 3% G+C.
It was isolated from surface mud (mouth of Kuban River).
Type strain 50.
The culture has been deposited at the Institute of Microbial Biochemistry and Physiology, Academy of Science of the USSR.
